Saturday, August 31, 2013

Rectangular Potential Barrier

Rectangular potential barriers, also called square potential barriers, are formed by energy potentials which create wall-like barricades for particles. Essentially, a potential barrier is a potential step except the energy potential returns to zero at some finite positive x-position, a, and remains zero beyond that point. Here, we'll derive the wave function of a particle facing a rectangular potential barrier, then find the transmission and reflection coefficients of the particle upon encountering the barrier.

Schrodinger Equations

Key to solving for the wave function of a particle hitting a potential barrier is finding the Schrodinger equations which describe the system. First, define the energy potential, V(x), of the system as this:
V(x)=⎧⎩⎨0,V0,0,x<00<x<ax>a(1)

Writing the wave function of the particle as ψ1(x) for x<0, ψ2(x) for 0<x<a, and ψ3(x) for x>a, the Schrodinger equations for x<0, 0<x<a, and x>a are respectively:
Eψ1(x)Eψ2(x)Eψ3(x)=−ℏ22md2dx2ψ1(x)=−ℏ22md2dx2ψ2(x)+V0ψ2(x)=−ℏ22md2dx2ψ3(x)(2)(3)(4)

This can be simplified, considering the wavenumbers, k1 and k2, of the wave function for inside and outside the barrier respectively. Since k12=2mE/ℏ2 and k22=2m(E−V0)/ℏ2, this can be said of the wave function of a particle with E≥V0.
000=d2dx2ψ1(x)+k12ψ1(x)=d2dx2ψ2(x)+k22ψ2(x)=d2dx2ψ3(x)+k12ψ3(x)(5)(6)(7)

Notice, however that if E<V0, k2 is imaginary and thus no longer an observable. By convention therefore, κ, defined by κ2=2m(V0−E)/ℏ2, is used instead for E<V0. The differential equations defining the wave function of a particle with insufficient energy are thus:
000=d2dx2ψ1(x)+k12ψ1(x)=d2dx2ψ2(x)−κ2ψ2(x)=d2dx2ψ3(x)+k12ψ3(x)(8)(9)(10)


If There Is Sufficient Energy

For E≥V0, to find the wave function of the particle, equations (5), (6), and (7) must be solved. These are homogeneous second-order linear differential equations and have the following general solutions:
ψ1(x)ψ2(x)ψ3(x)=AerAx+BerBx=CerCx+DerDx=FerFx+GerGx(11)(12)(13)

where A, B, C, D, F, and G are constants and rA=rF and rB=rG are the two solutions to the equation r2+k12=0 while rC and rD are the two solutions to the equation r2+k22=0.
ψ1(x)ψ2(x)ψ3(x)=Aeik1x+Be−ik1x=Ceik2x+De−ik2x=Feik1x+Ge−ik1x(14)(15)(16)

Notice, considering Euler's formula, that Aeik1x, Ceik2x, and Feik1x represent waves travelling in the positive direction while Be−ik1x, De−ik2x, and Ge−ik1x represent waves travelling in the negative direction. Since reflection by the barrier is conceivable, it is possible to have wave components travelling in the negative direction for x<a , but there is no reason to have waves doing so for x>a. Thus, G=0.
ψ1(x)ψ2(x)ψ3(x)=Aeik1x+Be−ik1x=Ceik2x+De−ik2x=Feik1x(17)(18)(19)

To solve for B and F in relation to A, impose these four boundary conditions to ensure that the wave function is a smooth curve as x→0 and as x→a:
limx→0−ψ1(x)limx→0−ddxψ1(x)limx→a−ψ2(x)limx→a−ddxψ2(x)=limx→0+ψ2(x)=limx→0+ddxψ2(x)=limx→a+ψ3(x)=limx→a+ddxψ3(x)

A+Bik1A−ik1BCeik2a+De−ik2aik2Ceik2a−ik2De−ik2a=C+D=ik2C−ik2D=Feik1a=ik1Feik1a(20)(21)(22)(23)

k1A+k1Bk1A−k1Bk2Ceik2a+k2De−ik2ak2Ceik2a−k2De−ik2a=k1C+k1D=k2C−k2D=k2Feik1a=k1Feik1a(24)(25)(26)(27)

2k1A2k1B2k2Ceik2a2k2De−ik2a=(k1+k2)C+(k1−k2)D=(k1−k2)C+(k1+k2)D=(k1+k2)Feik1a=(k2−k1)Feik1a(28)(29)(30)(31)

To solve for F in relation to A, consider equations (28), (30), and (31).
2k1A=(k1+k2)22k2Fei(k1−k2)a−(k1−k2)22k2Fei(k1+k2)a(32)

4k1k2e−ik1aA=(k1+k2)2Fe−ik2a−(k1−k2)2Feik2a(33)

Using Euler's formula to expand e−ik2a and eik2a, the following can be derived:
4k1k2e−ik1aA=(−2ik12sink2a+4k1k2cosk2a−2ik22sink2a)F(34)

F=2k1k2e−ik1aA2k1k2cosk2a−i(k12+k22)sink2a(35)

To solve for B in relation to A, consider equations (29), (30), and (31).
2k1B=k12−k222k2Fei(k1−k2)a−k12−k222k2Fei(k1+k2)a(36)

4k1k2e−ik1aBk12−k22=(e−ik2a−eik2a)F(37)

Using Euler's formula to expand e−ik2a and eik2a, the following can be derived:
2k1k2e−ik1aB−i(k12−k22)sink2a=F(38)

Comparing equations (35) and (38), B is solved for in relation to A.
B=−i(k12−k22)sin(k2a)A2k1k2cosk2a−i(k12+k22)sink2a(39)

Considering equations (30) and (31) alongside equation (35), C and D can also be solved for in relation to A, but since only A, B, and F are needed to calculate the reflection and transmission coefficients, the derivations of C and D are omitted here. In order to find the reflection and transmission coefficients, the wave function must be first written in terms of its incident, reflected, and transmitted components, ψi(x), ψr(x), and ψt(x) respectively.
ψi(x)ψr(x)ψt(x)=Aeik1x=Be−ik1x=Feik1x(40)(41)(42)

The reflection and transmission coefficients, R and T respectively, are defined as follows:
RT=−jrji=jtji(43)(44)

where ji, jr, and jt are the incident, reflected, and transmitted probability currents respectively.
RT=−ψr(x)ddxψr∗(x)−ψr∗(x)ddxψr(x)ψi(x)ddxψi∗(x)−ψi∗(x)ddxψi(x)=ψt(x)ddxψt∗(x)−ψt∗(x)ddxψt(x)ψi(x)ddxψi∗(x)−ψi∗(x)ddxψi(x)(45)(46)

RT=|B|2|A|2=|F|2|A|2(47)(48)

Applying the solutions for B and F found in equations (39) and (35) respectively gives:
RT=(k12−k22)2sin2k2a4k12k22cos2k2a+(k12+k22)2sin2k2a=4k12k224k12k22cos2k2a+(k12+k22)2sin2k2a(49)(50)

RT=(k12−k22)2sin2k2a4k12k22+(k12−k22)2sin2k2a=4k12k224k12k22+(k12−k22)2sin2k2a(51)(52)

RT=⎡⎣4k12k22(k12−k22)2sin2k2a+1⎤⎦−1=⎡⎣(k12−k22)2sin2k2a4k12k22+1⎤⎦−1(53)(54)

Interestingly contrary to classical mechanics, quantum mechanics suggests that the particle may actually be reflected by the potential barrier, despite having a total energy of equal or greater value than V0.

If There Is Insufficient Energy

For E<V0, equations (8), (9), and (10) must be solved to find ψ1(x), ψ2(x), and ψ3(x). To do this, follow the methodology employed in the previous section, "If There Is Sufficient Energy". The solutions of equations (8), (9), and (10) are identical to those of (5), (6), and (7) respectively save for the use of iκ in the place of k2.
ψ1(x)ψ2(x)ψ3(x)=Aeik1x+Be−ik1x=Ce−κx+Deκx=Feik1x(55)(56)(57)

Applying the same boundary conditions as in the previous section and manipulating algebra in the same manner, it can also be found that:
2ik1A2ik1B2κCe−κa2κDeκa=(ik1−κ)C+(ik1+κ)D=(ik1+κ)C+(ik1−κ)D=(κ−ik1)Feik1a=(ik1+κ)Feik1a(58)(59)(60)(61)

To solve for F in relation to A, consider equations (58), (60), and (61).
2ik1A=−(ik1−κ)22κFe(ik1+κ)a+(ik1+κ)22κFe(ik1−κ)a(62)

4ik1κe−ik1aA=−(ik1−κ)2Feκa+(ik1+κ)2Fe−κa(63)

4ik1κe−ik1aA=[(k12−κ2)(eκa−e−κa)+2ik1κ(eκa+e−κa)]F(64)

F=2ik1κe−ik1aA(k12−κ2)sinhκa+2ik1κcoshκa(65)

(In case you are unfamiliar with hyperbolic functions, sinhu=(eu−e−u)/2 is the hyperbolic sine function and coshu=(eu+e−u)/2 is the hyperbolic cosine function.) To solve for B in relation to A, consider equations (59), (60), and (61).
2ik1B=k12+κ22κFe(ik1+κ)a−k12+κ22κFe(ik1−κ)a(66)

4ik1κe−ik1aBk12+κ2=Feκa−Fe−κa(67)

2ik1κe−ik1aB(k12+κ2)sinhκa=F(68)

Comparing equations (65) and (68), B is solved for in relation to A.
B=(k12+κ2)sinh(κa)A(k12−κ2)sinhκa+2ik1κcoshκa(69)

As in the previous section, the wave function written in terms of its incident, reflected, and transmitted components is:
ψi(x)ψr(x)ψt(x)=Aeik1x=Be−ik1x=Feik1x(70)(71)(72)

Furthermore, the reflection and transmission coefficients, derivable using the same method as in the previous section, are again given by:
RT=|B|2|A|2=|F|2|A|2(73)(74)

RT=(k12+κ2)2sinh2κa(k12−κ2)2sinh2κa+4k12κ2cosh2κa=4k12κ2(k12−κ2)2sinh2κa+4k12κ2cosh2κa(75)(76)

RT=(k12+κ2)2sinh2κa(k12+κ2)2sinh2κa+4k12κ2=4k12κ2(k12+κ2)2sinh2κa+4k12κ2(77)(78)

RT=⎡⎣4k12κ2(k12+κ2)2sinh2κa+1⎤⎦−1=⎡⎣(k12+κ2)2sinh2κa4k12κ2+1⎤⎦−1(79)(80)

Contrary to classical expectations which would suggest that the particle has zero probability of travelling beyond x=0, quantum mechanics asserts that the particle has a non-zero probability of tunneling through the rectangular potential barrier, despite having a total energy less than V0. This phenomenon marks a major difference between quantum and classical mechanics.
